dir-section.heading: Trade Unions
dir-section.p: At the end of 2023 some 5,323,500 employees in Canada—30.4% of the total—were covered by a union collective bargaining agreement or union contract. More than two-thirds of unionized workers in 2015 were represented by the Canadian Labour Congress. In 2015 some 69.7% of unionized workers belonged to national unions and 24.9% belonged to international unions (with headquarters outside of Canada).

Unionization rates displayed considerable regional variation: in 2023 a total of 39.6% of employees in Newfoundland and Labrador, and 38.9% of employees in Québec, were covered by a collective agreement, while Alberta had the lowest union coverage rate, at 24.9%, behind Ontario (26.3%). In 2023 a total of 76.7% of public sector employees were covered by a collective agreement or union contract, compared with 15.5% of private sector employees.
